noun.description: A particular kind of matter with uniform properties.
examples: a steel tube coated with a waxy substance

noun.description: The real physical matter of which a person or thing consists and which has a tangible, solid presence.
examples: proteins compose much of the actual substance of the body

noun.description: The quality of being important, valid, or significant.
examples: he had yet to accomplish anything of substance

noun.description: The essential nature underlying phenomena, which is subject to changes and accidents.

phrases: basic rights are equivalent in substance to human rights
Such restrictions cannot however be regarded as equivalent in substance to a prohibition on manufacture and marketing.
The distinction between a 2.2 and 2.1 is not, in substance, a difference of a few decimal points.
This can be illustrated briefly with references to two examples that are very different in substance but identical in principle.
The one argument is it is in substance a transactional tax.
origin: Middle English (denoting the essential nature of something): from Old French, from Latin substantia being, essence, from substant- standing firm, from the verb substare.
